messageBody:
Robert Martin wrote:

> > I'll just repeat what I said in my previous email: most of the
> > software out
> > there is 1) not tested and 2) works great.
>
> Non Sequitur. Your facts are not coordinated.

Let me re-interpret, in the interest of moving this discussion along,
because I find it useful.

Most of the software out there is (1) only tested by customer use and
(2) seems to work well enough to satisfy the customers.

I can agree with this; however, I will point out that our industry has
done a good job over the past two decades (that I've seen) of training
users to expect less from us, by virtue of the crap we put out there.

Here's a simple example. I want a WYSIWYG HTML editor to write weblog
entries. All I need to do is write the weblog entry, then switch to the
"Source" view, then copy the contents into my weblog entry form. I have
tried four different HTML editors for the Mac before I found one that
didn't suck. Mostly, here is how they have sucked:

* One of them wouldn't insert a new <p> tag when I pressed ENTER; it
would assume I meant <br>
* One of them would insert a bunch of <br> tags in my code samples
(surrounding by <pre> tags), which doesn't actually work properly in all
browsers
* Two of them didn't do WYSIWYG even remotely well.
* One of them inserted   instead of regular spaces inside <pre> tags

All these products probably have loyal followings--dozens, hundreds,
even thousands of users--and yet they have simple, silly problems that
would easily have been fixed by the slightest amount of attention to
adhering to the HTML standard. The tests don't get any easier than that.

So we, as a user community, don't demand enough of software teams. If we
demanded more, programmers would have little choice but to test more.

It's an open question to me whether that day will ever come, but I have
found that TDD makes me so faster, not slower, so I get to market sooner
either way.

Take care.
